title: Animal rights group PETA propose a roadside memorial for CHICKENS who died in fiery truck crash
text:
Animal rights activists have called for a roadside memorial to pay tribute to chickens who were burned alive when a truck caught fire.

The rear of a B-double truck carrying a load of chickens was set alight on the Northern Expressway in Adelaide about 4am on Wednesday.

The chickens who survived the inferno will have to be euthanised, according to South Australia Police.

PETA have written to the state's Department of Planning, Transport and Infrastructure [DPTI] for approval to erect a roadside tombstone memorial at the crash site.

The tribute would feature an image of a chicken next to the words 'In Memory of the Chickens Who Suffered and Died at This Spot. Try Vegan.'

The fire was extinguished by the Metropolitan Fire Service [MFS].

The driver was not injured in the incident.

The tribute would feature an image of a chicken next to the words: 'In Memory of the Chickens Who Suffered and Died at This Spot. Try Vegan.'

'Animals raised and killed for food suffer from the day they're born until the day they're loaded on trucks for the terrifying journey to the abattoir, where their throats are cut - sometimes while they're still conscious,' PETA spokeswoman Emily Rice told Daily Mail Australia.

'We hope our memorial will prompt people not to eat animals or - at the absolute least - remind truck drivers to make animals' transport to slaughter as safe and comfortable as possible.'
description: The rear of a B-double truck carrying a load of chickens was set alight on the Northern Expressway in Adelaide at about 4am on Wednesday.
authors: Paula Ahillon For Daily Mail Australia
